security: Disclosure of details regarding the AMTIM group's operations, planned air-maritime operations, and assessments of various individuals involved in anti-Castro activities could jeopardize ongoing operations and endanger the lives of individuals mentioned in the report. Quoting the document, "Rogers then briefly discussed the SINNE operation and asked AMRUNG-1 if he didn't think this area for the DZ was already 'flown' due to the number of people who already knew of his operation." and "AMRUNG-1 considers RAY as a highly dangerous individual because of his great ambition to play a prominent role in any subsequent Cuban government following the overthrow of the Castro regime."
summary: John D. Peters reports on a meeting with AMRUNG-1, a leader of the AMTIM group in Cuba, discussing operational support, security concerns, and assessments of other anti-Castro groups and leaders.
summary_one_paragraph: On November 8, 1960, John D. Peters documented a meeting with AMRUNG-1, a leader of the AMTIM group in Cuba, focusing on security measures, operational expenditures, and support for anti-Castro groups. The meeting, held after AMRUNG-1's arrival in Washington and an interview with W/T operator Francisco, involved discussions about supplying the AMTIM group with arms and ammo, the SINNE operation, and evaluations of potential landing zones. AMRUNG-1 expressed concerns about internal security in Cuba, the need for increased financial support, and the weaknesses in current communication methods, while also sharing his views on other anti-Castro leaders like Manolo Ray and Tony Varona and their potential impact on the FRENTE's effectiveness.
title: Contact Report on Meeting with AMRURO-1
